name: Age of Enlightenment
summary: Intellectual movement emphasizing reason, science, and individual rights over tradition and religious authority; philosophers like Voltaire, Locke, and Rousseau challenged absolutism and laid foundations for modern democracy
related person 1: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe (1749–1832): Embodied Enlightenment ideals through his literary and scientific works.
related event 1: Classical period (music) (1750–1820): Musical style reflected Enlightenment values of balance and rational form.
related event 2: French Revolution (1789–1799): Revolutionary ideals drew heavily from Enlightenment philosophy about rights and reason.
related event 3: Napoleonic Wars (1803–1815): Post-Enlightenment conflicts tested and spread Enlightenment political ideas.
notes: Key ideas: natural rights, separation of powers, social contract, religious tolerance. Major centers: France (philosophes), Scotland (Scottish Enlightenment), Germany (Aufklärung). The movement's dates are often marked from Newton's Principia (1687) to the French Revolution (1789).

name: American Civil War
summary: A major conflict in the United States between the Union and the Confederacy, primarily over slavery and states’ rights; it reshaped global views on democracy, warfare, and emancipation.
related person 1: Abraham Lincoln (1809–1865): Led the Union and made abolition of slavery a central war aim.
related person 2: Robert E. Lee (1807–1870): Commanded the main Confederate army and shaped the conflict’s military course.
related person 3: Ulysses S. Grant (1822–1885): Union general whose victories were decisive in winning the war.
related event 1: Expansion of Railways (1830–1870): Rail networks played a crucial role in troop and supply movements.
related event 2: Industrial Revolution (c. 1760–c. 1840): Industrialization created economic and social divisions between North and South.
related event 3: Second Industrial Revolution (1870–1914): Postwar growth accelerated industrial and technological change.
notes: European powers—especially Britain and France—considered recognizing the Confederacy but ultimately stayed neutral. The war accelerated technological warfare developments like ironclads, rail logistics, and rapid telegraph communication.

name: Appomattox Campaign
summary: Final military campaign of the Civil War ending with Lee's surrender to Grant at Appomattox Court House; marked the effective end of the war.
related person 1: Andrew Johnson (1808–1875): President who formally declared the war's end on August 20, 1866.
related person 2: Robert E. Lee (1807–1870): Confederate general who surrendered the Army of Northern Virginia.
related person 3: Ulysses S. Grant (1822–1885): Union general who commanded forces and accepted Lee's surrender.
related event 1: American Civil War (1861–1865): This campaign was the final phase of the war.
related event 2: Emancipation Proclamation (Proclamation 95) (1863): The surrender secured the proclamation's promise.
related event 3: Thirteenth Amendment to the US Constitution (1865): Surrender enabled the amendment's ratification.
notes: Campaign ran March 29–April 9, 1865. Included battles at Five Forks (April 1) and Sailor's Creek (April 6). Lee surrendered to Grant on April 9, 1865 at Appomattox Court House. Generous terms allowed Confederate soldiers to return home if they pledged to end fighting. War formally declared ended by President Johnson on August 20, 1866.

name: Assassination of Alexander II
summary: Revolutionary terrorists from Narodnaya Volya assassinated Tsar Alexander II with bombs in St. Petersburg; marked the high point of Russian revolutionary terrorism and end of reform era.
related person 1: Alexander II of Russia (1818–1881): Tsar killed by second bomb after exiting damaged carriage.
related person 2: Alexander III of Russia (1845–1894): brought to power and shaped his reactionary policies
related event 1: Emancipation of the Serfs (1861): His major reform that failed to satisfy revolutionaries.
related event 2: Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878): Recent conflict he led.
related event 3: Victorian Era (1837–1901): Contemporary period.
notes: Occurred March 13, 1881 in St. Petersburg. First bomb by Nikolai Rysakov damaged imperial carriage. When Alexander exited to check wounded, Ignacy Hryniewiecki threw second bomb at his feet, fatally wounding both himself and the Tsar. Six conspirators including organizer Sophia Perovskaya were executed April 15, 1881. Assassination planned by Narodnaya Volya (People's Will) revolutionary group hoping to spark revolution.

name: Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand
summary: Austro-Hungarian heir Franz Ferdinand and his wife Sophie assassinated in Sarajevo by Bosnian Serb student Gavrilo Princip; triggered July Crisis and outbreak of World War I.
related person 1: Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria (1863–1914): Archduke and heir presumptive to Austro-Hungarian throne, assassinated with his wife.
related event 1: Austro-Hungarian Compromise (1867): Established the dual monarchy that Franz Ferdinand would have inherited.
related event 2: Scramble for Africa (1881–1914): Period of imperial competition that contributed to European tensions.
related event 3: Victorian Era (1837–1901): Late Victorian era context of European power politics.
notes: Occurred June 28, 1914 in Sarajevo. Princip was 19-year-old member of Young Bosnia seeking to free Bosnia from Austrian rule. Chauffeur took wrong turn, stopped and reversed, giving Princip opportunity to shoot both Franz Ferdinand and Sophie at point-blank range. Set off July Crisis leading to World War I outbreak within one month. Princip sentenced to 20 years (too young for death penalty), died of tuberculosis in prison 1918.

name: Austro-Hungarian Compromise
summary: Agreement establishing the Dual Monarchy of Austria-Hungary, granting Hungary full internal autonomy while maintaining single state for war and foreign affairs.
related person 1: Ferenc Deák (1803–1876): Hungarian statesman who negotiated the compromise.
related person 2: Franz Joseph I of Austria (1830–1916): Emperor who agreed to the compromise and was crowned King of Hungary on June 8, 1867.
related person 3: Gyula Andrássy (1823–1890): Hungarian political leader who helped negotiate and became first Prime Minister of Hungary under the Dual Monarchy.
related event 1: Austro-Prussian War (1866): Austria's defeat weakened its position and made compromise with Hungary necessary.
related event 2: Hungarian Revolution of 1848–1849 (1848–1849): The compromise ended absolutist rule imposed after this failed revolution.
related event 3: Victorian Era (1837–1901): Contemporary period.
notes: Concluded February 8, 1867. Created dual monarchy where Austria and Hungary were equal partners under one monarch. Hungary gained full internal autonomy with responsible ministry. Franz Joseph crowned King of Hungary June 8, 1867. According to Franz Joseph: "There were three of us who made the agreement: Deák, Andrássy and myself."

name: Austro-Prussian War
summary: Conflict between Austria and Prussia for dominance in Germany.
related person 1: Helmuth von Moltke the Elder (1800–1891): Planned and executed Prussian military strategy in the war.
related person 2: Otto von Bismarck (1815–1898): Engineered the conflict to exclude Austria from German affairs.
related person 3: Wilhelm I (1797–1888): Prussian king under whom victory paved the way to German unification.
related event 1: Franco-Prussian War (1870–1871): Follow-up conflict that finalized unification.
related event 2: Revolutions of 1848 (1848–1849): Earlier struggles influenced nationalist rivalries between Austria and Prussia.
related event 3: Unification of Germany (1866–1871): Cleared the way for Prussian leadership of Germany.
notes: Paved the way for Prussian leadership in German unification.

name: Battle of Trafalgar
summary: Decisive British naval victory over combined French-Spanish fleet; established British naval supremacy for over a century but resulted in Admiral Nelson's death.
related person 1: Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson (1758–1805): British admiral who commanded the Royal Navy fleet and died during the battle.
related person 2: Napoleon Bonaparte (1769–1821): French emperor whose planned invasion of Britain depended on winning naval control.
related event 1: Congress of Vienna (1814–1815): Post-Napoleonic settlement.
related event 2: French Invasion of Russia (1812): Napoleon's later major campaign.
related event 3: Napoleonic Wars (1803–1815): Trafalgar was a decisive naval battle of the wars.
notes: Fought October 21, 1805 off Cape Trafalgar, Spain. British fleet of 27 ships defeated Franco-Spanish fleet of 33 ships. Nelson's innovative tactics broke enemy line at right angles. Nelson killed by French musketeer during battle. Franco-Spanish lost 19-20 ships and 14,000 men; British lost no ships, 1,500 casualties. Ended Napoleon's invasion plans and secured British naval supremacy.

name: Battle of Waterloo
summary: Napoleon's final defeat by Wellington and Blücher; ended the Hundred Days and the Napoleonic Wars.
related person 1: Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington (1769–1852): Commanded the allied army that defeated Napoleon.
related person 2: Gebhard Leberecht von Blücher (1742–1819): Led the Prussian army whose arrival turned the tide of battle.
related person 3: Napoleon Bonaparte (1769–1821): Led French forces in his final battle before second abdication and exile.
related event 1: Congress of Vienna (1814–1815): The post-war settlement was ongoing when Waterloo was fought.
related event 2: French Revolution (1789–1799): The wars grew out of revolutionary France.
related event 3: Napoleonic Wars (1803–1815): The Battle of Waterloo was the final battle of the Napoleonic Wars.
notes: Fought on June 18, 1815. Napoleon's delay waiting for dry ground allowed Prussian reinforcements to arrive, sealing his defeat.

name: Classical period (music)
summary: Era of classical music falling between the Baroque and Romantic periods.
related person 1: Joseph Haydn (1732–1809): Prolific composer whose symphonies and string quartets helped define the classical style.
related person 2: Ludwig van Beethoven (1770–1827): Bridged the Classical and Romantic periods with his innovative compositions.
related event 1: Age of Enlightenment (1687–1789): The intellectual movement that shaped classical music's emphasis on clarity and order.
related event 2: Napoleonic Wars (1803–1815): Occurred during the late Classical period and influenced composers like Beethoven.
notes: The best-known composers from this period are Joseph Haydn, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Ludwig van Beethoven, and Franz Schubert.

name: Concert of Europe
summary: Diplomatic system of balance of power among European great powers established after the Napoleonic Wars to maintain stability and prevent major conflicts.
related person 1: Alexander I of Russia (1777–1825): Russian emperor and one of the leading personalities maintaining the system.
related person 2: Klemens von Metternich (1773–1859): Austrian chancellor who chaired the Congress of Vienna and was a leading architect of the Concert system.
related person 3: Robert Stewart, Viscount Castlereagh (1769–1822): British foreign secretary who was instrumental in establishing the Concert.
related event 1: Congress of Vienna (1814–1815): Established the Concert of Europe system.
related event 2: Napoleonic Wars (1803–1815): The Concert was created to prevent recurrence of such conflicts.
related event 3: Revolutions of 1848 (1848–1849): Challenged the Concert system and marked the end of its original form.
notes: System of periodic conferences among five great powers (Britain, Russia, Austria, Prussia, France) to maintain balance of power and suppress revolutionary movements. Challenged by revolutions of 1830 and especially 1848, which combined nationalist and liberal ideas against the conservative order.

name: Congress of Angostura
summary: Revolutionary congress convened by Bolívar that proclaimed Gran Colombia, uniting Venezuela, New Granada, and Quito; Bolívar delivered his influential address on constitutional government.
related person 1: Francisco de Paula Santander (1792–1840): Appointed vice president of Gran Colombia at the congress.
related person 2: Simón Bolívar (1783–1830): Convened the congress and delivered his famous address on February 15, 1819.
related event 1: Napoleonic Wars (1803–1815): European conflicts provided context for Latin American independence movements.
related event 2: Venezuelan War of Independence (1810–1823): The congress was convened during the independence struggle.
related event 3: Victorian Era (1837–1901): Later contemporary period.
notes: Opened February 15, 1819, in Angostura (today Ciudad Bolívar). Bolívar delivered address warning against imitating Anglo-American institutions and advocating centralized government with hereditary Senate. December 17, 1819, congress proclaimed Gran Colombia through the Fundamental Law of the Republic, uniting Venezuela, New Granada, and Quito. Bolívar appointed president, Santander vice president. Full constitution later written by Congress of Cúcuta (1821).

name: Congress of Berlin
summary: Major diplomatic conference that revised the Treaty of San Stefano ending the Russo-Turkish War; redrew Balkan borders and maintained European balance of power.
related person 1: Alexander II of Russia (1818–1881): Russian tsar whose gains from the Russo-Turkish War were reduced by the congress.
related person 2: Benjamin Disraeli (1804–1881): British Prime Minister who secured Cyprus and limited Russian expansion.
related person 3: Otto von Bismarck (1815–1898): German Chancellor who chaired the congress as "honest broker".
related event 1: Concert of Europe (1815–c. 1848): Continuation of the balance of power diplomatic tradition.
related event 2: Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878): The congress revised the war's peace settlement.
related event 3: Victorian Era (1837–1901): Contemporary period, part of 19th century European diplomacy.
notes: Held June 13-July 13, 1878. Reduced Bulgaria's size from Treaty of San Stefano. Granted full independence to Serbia, Romania, Montenegro. Austria-Hungary occupied Bosnia-Herzegovina. Britain gained Cyprus. Bismarck played neutral mediator role. Demonstrated continued European great power diplomacy.

name: Congress of Vienna
summary: Diplomatic conference to restore European order after the Napoleonic Wars.
related person 1: Alexander I of Russia (1777–1825): One of the leading monarchs who redrew Europe’s map after Napoleon.
related person 2: Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington (1769–1852): Represented British interests at the peace negotiations.
related person 3: Ludwig van Beethoven (1770–1827): Lived in Vienna and composed works reflecting the era of Napoleonic conflict.
related event 1: Crimean War (1853–1856): Rivalries within the Vienna system contributed to later great-power conflicts.
related event 2: Napoleonic Wars (1803–1815): The congress was convened to settle the outcome of the wars.
related event 3: Revolutions of 1848 (1848–1849): The conservative order created in Vienna was challenged by later revolutions.
notes: Established a balance-of-power system that shaped Europe for decades.

name: Crimean War
summary: Conflict between the Russian Empire and an alliance of the Ottoman Empire, Britain, and France. Russia came out significantly weakened.
related person 1: Alexander II of Russia (1818–1881): Tsar who inherited the conflict and its consequences for Russian reform.
related person 2: Karl Marx (1818–1883): Commentated on the war as a journalist and critic of European diplomacy.
related person 3: Queen Victoria (1819–1901): British monarch during the war, which involved major British deployment.
related event 1: Congress of Vienna (1814–1815): Tested the balance-of-power system established at Vienna.
related event 2: Scramble for Africa (1881–1914): Imperial rivalries evident in Crimea later extended into colonial competition.
related event 3: Unification of Italy (Risorgimento) (1848–1871): Piedmont’s role in the war raised its international standing.
notes: One of the first modern wars, with railways, telegraphs, and war reporting.

name: Emancipation of the Serfs
summary: Alexander II freed over 23 million Russian serfs, granting them rights of free citizens; major modernization reform prompted by Crimean War defeat.
related person 1: Alexander II of Russia (1818–1881): Issued the Emancipation Manifesto to modernize Russia and prevent revolution from below.
related event 1: Assassination of Alexander II (1881): He was assassinated partly due to dissatisfaction with pace of reforms.
related event 2: Crimean War (1853–1856): Defeat exposed Russia's backwardness and prompted reforms.
related event 3: Victorian Era (1837–1901): Contemporary with broader 19th century reform movements.
notes: Issued March 3, 1861. While serfs gained personal freedom and were promised land, the acquisition process was slow and expensive.

name: Emancipation Proclamation (Proclamation 95)
summary: Presidential proclamation issued by Lincoln declaring freedom for enslaved people in Confederate states; transformed the Civil War into a war to end slavery and enabled Black soldiers to join Union forces.
related person 1: Abraham Lincoln (1809–1865): President who issued the proclamation as a war measure.
related person 2: Frederick Douglass (1818–1895): Leading abolitionist who advocated for the proclamation and Black military service.
related event 1: American Civil War (1861–1865): Issued during the war, transformed its purpose to include ending slavery.
related event 2: Thirteenth Amendment to the US Constitution (1865): Completed the work by permanently abolishing slavery.
related event 3: Victorian Era (1837–1901): Contemporary period.
notes: Issued January 1, 1863. Declared free all enslaved people in rebellious states. Did not apply to border states or areas under Union control. Enabled nearly 200,000 Black soldiers and sailors to fight for the Union. Prevented European intervention on behalf of Confederacy by making the war about ending slavery.

name: Expansion of Railways
summary: Rapid spread of railway networks that transformed travel and industry.
related person 1: George Stephenson (1781–1848): Helped pioneer railway technology adopted across Europe.
related person 2: Isambard Kingdom Brunel (1806–1859): Built major railway lines that demonstrated the potential of rail transport.
related person 3: Queen Victoria (1819–1901): Her use of rail travel popularized the new mode of transportation.
related event 1: Industrial Revolution (c. 1760–c. 1840): Grew out of earlier industrial advances in steam and iron.
related event 2: Scramble for Africa (1881–1914): Railroads became tools of colonial control and resource extraction.
related event 3: Second Industrial Revolution (1870–1914): Laid infrastructure later used for heavy industry and mass production.
notes: Enabled mass transportation, urban growth, and national integration.

name: Expedition of the Thousand
summary: Garibaldi's volunteer force of about 1,000 "redshirts" conquered Sicily and southern Italy from Bourbon rule; crucial military campaign in Italian unification.
related person 1: Camillo Benso, Count of Cavour (1810–1861): Sardinian Prime Minister who worked with Garibaldi's achievement toward unification.
related person 2: Giuseppe Garibaldi (1807–1882): Led the expedition and conquered the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies.
related person 3: Victor Emmanuel II (1820–1878): King who received Garibaldi's conquests on October 26, 1860.
related event 1: Second Italian War of Independence (1859): Earlier war that set the stage for Garibaldi's expedition.
related event 2: Unification of Italy (Risorgimento) (1848–1871): This expedition was the decisive military campaign that made unification possible.
related event 3: Victorian Era (1837–1901): Contemporary period.
notes: Departed Genoa May 5, landed Marsala May 11, 1860. Conquered Sicily in three months through battles at Calatafimi (May 15) and Palermo (June 6). Crossed to mainland August 20, entered Naples September 7. Garibaldi relinquished dictatorship to Victor Emmanuel October 26. Led to Kingdom of Italy proclamation March 1861.

name: First International
summary: First international organization uniting socialist and labor movements; founded by Marx and others, dissolved after splits between communists and anarchists.
related person 1: Karl Marx (1818–1883): Led the General Council and wrote the organization's founding documents.
related person 2: Mikhail Bakunin (1814–1876): Leading anarchist whose conflict with Marx led to the International's split in 1872.
related event 1: Paris Commune (1871): Major revolutionary event that occurred during the First International's existence.
related event 2: Revolutions of 1848 (1848–1849): Earlier revolutionary wave that influenced socialist movements.
related event 3: Victorian Era (1837–1901): Occurred during this period, part of 19th century political movements.
notes: Also known as the International Workingmen's Association. Established theoretical foundations for modern socialism, communism, and anarchism.

name: Franco-Prussian War
summary: War between France and Prussia that led to German unification.
related person 1: Helmuth von Moltke the Elder (1800–1891): Commanded German forces to victory over France.
related person 2: Napoleon III (1808–1873): French emperor, born Louis-Napoléon Bonaparte, defeated and deposed in the conflict.
related person 3: Otto von Bismarck (1815–1898): Used the war to rally German states and complete unification.
related event 1: Paris Commune (1871): The siege and defeat of Paris helped trigger the Commune.
related event 2: Second French Republic (1848–1852): The fall of the Second Empire led to yet another French republican experiment.
related event 3: Unification of Germany (1866–1871): Its outcome directly produced the German Empire.
notes: Ended the French Empire and enabled the proclamation of the German Empire.

name: French Invasion of Egypt and Syria
summary: Napoleon's military expedition to Egypt and Syria; initially successful with victories at the Pyramids, but undermined by naval defeat at Aboukir Bay and failed siege of Acre; resulted in French scientific discoveries including the Rosetta Stone.
related person 1: Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson (1758–1805): Destroyed the French fleet at the Battle of the Nile, stranding Napoleon's army in Egypt.
related person 2: Napoleon Bonaparte (1769–1821): Commanded the expedition seeking to threaten British India and establish French presence in the East.
related event 1: Congress of Vienna (1814–1815): Later event that dealt with Napoleon's legacy.
related event 2: French Revolution (1789–1799): The expedition occurred during the Revolutionary period.
related event 3: Napoleonic Wars (1803–1815): This expedition was a precursor to the Napoleonic Wars.
notes: Expedition departed Toulon May 19, 1798. Captured Malta June 12. Battle of the Pyramids July 21 defeated Mamluks. Nelson destroyed French fleet at Battle of the Nile (Aboukir Bay) August 1-3, 1798, stranding French army. Napoleon advanced into Syria but failed to capture Acre after two-month siege (March-May 1799). Napoleon departed Egypt August 23, 1799, leaving General Kléber in command. French forces finally surrendered to British September 1801. Commission des Sciences et des Arts discovered Rosetta Stone in 1799.

name: French Invasion of Russia
summary: Napoleon’s failed campaign into Russia, marked by massive losses.
related person 1: Alexander I of Russia (1777–1825): Defended the Russian Empire against Napoleon’s invasion.
related person 2: Mikhail Kutuzov (1745–1813): Russian commander whose strategy of retreat and scorched earth devastated Napoleon's army
related person 3: Napoleon Bonaparte (1769–1821): Launched the ill-fated invasion that devastated his Grande Armée.
related event 1: Congress of Vienna (1814–1815): The invasion’s failure led eventually to the peace negotiations.
related event 2: Napoleonic Wars (1803–1815): One of the decisive turning points of the war.
related event 3: Peninsular War (1808–1814): Coincided with other costly campaigns that weakened France.
notes: The disastrous retreat severely weakened France’s military power.

name: French Revolution
summary: Political and social upheaval that ended the French monarchy and reshaped Europe.
related person 1: Karl Marx (1818–1883): Analyzed the Revolution as a key example of class struggle.
related person 2: Louis Blanc (1811–1882): Later interpreted and wrote about the Revolution in the context of social justice.
related person 3: Marie Antoinette (1755–1793): the last Queen of France before the fall of the monarchy during the French Revolution. She was executed.
related person 4: Napoleon Bonaparte (1769–1821): Rose to prominence as a military leader in the revolutionary wars.
related event 1: Congress of Vienna (1814–1815): Aimed to restore order after the revolutionary and Napoleonic era.
related event 2: Napoleonic Wars (1803–1815): Revolutionary France’s conflicts evolved into the Napoleonic Wars.
related event 3: Paris Commune (1871): Later radical movements in Paris drew on revolutionary traditions.
notes: Introduced radical reforms and inspired revolutionary movements worldwide.

name: Great Exhibition
summary: First world's fair showcasing industrial and cultural achievements; held in the Crystal Palace and attracted 6 million visitors.
related person 1: Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha (1819–1861): Principal organizer and driving force behind the Great Exhibition.
related person 2: Queen Victoria (1819–1901): Opened the exhibition and was heavily involved in its planning.
related event 1: Industrial Revolution (c. 1760–c. 1840): Showcased the achievements of industrialization.
related event 2: Second Industrial Revolution (1870–1914): Led into further technological advancement.
related event 3: Victorian Era (1837–1901): The Great Exhibition was the defining cultural event of the era.
notes: Generated £186,000 surplus used to found the V&A Museum, Science Museum, and Natural History Museum.

name: Hungarian Revolution of 1848–1849
summary: Hungarian uprising against Habsburg rule seeking independence and liberal reforms; inspired by wider European revolutions but crushed by combined Austrian and Russian forces.
related person 1: Franz Joseph I of Austria (1830–1916): Emperor who called in Russian military aid to crush the revolution.
related person 2: Lajos Kossuth (1802–1894): Political leader who became virtual dictator and head of state after Hungary declared independence.
related person 3: Nicholas I of Russia (1796–1855): Tsar who sent 300,000+ troops to help Austria defeat Hungary.
related event 1: Congress of Vienna (1814–1815): Established the Habsburg dominance over Hungary that revolutionaries sought to overthrow.
related event 2: Revolutions of 1848 (1848–1849): The Hungarian Revolution was part of this wider wave of European revolutions.
related event 3: Victorian Era (1837–1901): Contemporary period during which this occurred.
notes: Revolution began March 15, 1848, with 12 points of demands including press freedom and independent Hungarian ministry. Hungary declared independence and dethroned the Habsburgs on April 14, 1849. Crushed by Austro-Russian forces; last Hungarian units surrendered August 13, 1849. Followed by harsh Austrian martial law until 1867.

name: Indian Rebellion
summary: Major uprising by Indian soldiers and civilians against British East India Company rule; led to direct British Crown control of India.
related person 1: Bahadur Shah Zafar (1775–1862): Last Mughal emperor, nominally restored to power by rebels in Delhi.
related person 2: Queen Victoria (1819–1901): Became Empress of India following the rebellion's suppression.
related person 3: Rani of Jhansi (1828–1858): Queen of Jhansi who led one of the most famous resistance campaigns against the British.
related event 1: Crimean War (1853–1856): British military context of the period, shortly before the rebellion.
related event 2: Scramble for Africa (1881–1914): Part of broader 19th century imperial expansion.
related event 3: Victorian Era (1837–1901): Occurred during Victoria's reign, led to major changes in British India policy.
notes: Also known as the Sepoy Mutiny. Led to the dissolution of the East India Company and establishment of the British Raj under the Crown.

name: Industrial Revolution
summary: Transition to mechanized production, steam power, and factories; massive changes in work, population, and technology.
related person 1: George Stephenson (1781–1848): Pioneered steam locomotives, making rail transport a hallmark of industrial change.
related person 2: Isambard Kingdom Brunel (1806–1859): Engineered railways and bridges that became icons of industrial engineering.
related person 3: James Watt (1736–1819): Improved the steam engine, helping to trigger the shift to mechanized industry.
related event 1: American Civil War (1861–1865): Industrial capacity, especially in the North, shaped the course of the conflict.
related event 2: Expansion of Railways (1830–1870): Railway construction was a major outcome and driver of industrialization.
related event 3: Second Industrial Revolution (1870–1914): Built upon earlier industrial changes with new technologies and industries.
notes: Child labor laws, public health reforms, and modern labor movements all emerged as direct responses to industrial society’s problems.

name: Napoleonic Wars
summary: A series of major European conflicts led by Napoleon’s French Empire against various coalitions.
related person 1: Alexander I of Russia (1777–1825): Allied against Napoleon and played a key role in his eventual defeat.
related person 2: Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington (1769–1852): Commanded British and allied forces, defeating Napoleon at Waterloo.
related person 3: Napoleon Bonaparte (1769–1821): Led France in a series of campaigns that reshaped Europe.
related event 1: Congress of Vienna (1814–1815): Settlement that ended the wars and reshaped Europe.
related event 2: French Revolution (1789–1799): The wars grew out of the revolutionary upheavals in France.
related event 3: Peninsular War (1808–1814): One of the major campaigns of the broader Napoleonic conflict.
notes: These wars dramatically redrew Europe’s borders and spread Napoleonic legal reforms far beyond France. They also accelerated nationalism in Germany, Italy, and Spain.

name: Paris Commune
summary: Radical socialist government that briefly ruled Paris.
related person 1: Karl Marx (1818–1883): Celebrated the Commune as a prototype of proletarian government.
related person 2: Louis Blanc (1811–1882): Long-time advocate of social republicanism whose ideas resonated with Communards.
related person 3: Victor Hugo (1802–1885): Reflected on Parisian upheavals in his political and literary work.
related event 1: Franco-Prussian War (1870–1871): The defeat of France and siege of Paris set the stage for the Commune.
related event 2: French Revolution (1789–1799): Communards drew inspiration from earlier revolutionary traditions.
related event 3: Second French Republic (1848–1852): Its collapse and the failure of moderate republicanism helped radicalize Parisian politics.
notes: Regarded as an early precursor to later socialist and revolutionary movements.

name: Peninsular War
summary: Conflict in Iberia against Napoleon, involving Spain, Portugal, and Britain.
related person 1: Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington (1769–1852): Led British forces in Spain and Portugal against Napoleon.
related person 2: Ludwig van Beethoven (1770–1827): Reacted artistically to the anti-Napoleonic struggle in works like “Wellington’s Victory”.
related person 3: Napoleon Bonaparte (1769–1821): Ordered the invasion of the Iberian Peninsula in his struggle with Britain.
related event 1: Congress of Vienna (1814–1815): Diplomats later addressed the consequences of these campaigns.
related event 2: French Invasion of Russia (1812): Another major campaign that strained Napoleon’s resources.
related event 3: Napoleonic Wars (1803–1815): Fought as part of the wider struggle between Napoleon and his enemies.
notes: A major drain on French resources and a turning point against Napoleon.

name: Peruvian War of Independence
summary: Independence struggle led first by San Martín who declared independence in 1821, then by Bolívar who secured final victory; culminated in the decisive battles of Junín and Ayacucho in 1824, ending Spanish rule in South America.
related person 1: Antonio José de Sucre (1795–1830): Commanded the decisive Battle of Ayacucho in 1824.
related person 2: José de San Martín (1778–1850): Led the Liberating Expedition from the south, declared independence July 28, 1821, and served as Protector.
related person 3: Simón Bolívar (1783–1830): Led the northern expedition, took command after San Martín's departure in 1822.
related event 1: Congress of Angostura (1819): Bolívar's earlier revolutionary congress.
related event 2: Napoleonic Wars (1803–1815): Weakened Spanish colonial control.
related event 3: Venezuelan War of Independence (1810–1823): Part of the broader South American independence struggle.
notes: San Martín landed at Pisco September 1820. Independence declared July 28, 1821 in Lima. Guayaquil Conference July 26, 1822 between San Martín and Bolívar to decide Peru's political fate; San Martín departed September 22, 1822. Bolívar arrived Lima December 10, 1823. Battle of Junín August 6, 1824 commanded by Bolívar. Battle of Ayacucho December 9, 1824 commanded by Sucre secured independence of Peru and all South America.

name: Publication of On the Origin of Species
summary: Darwin's groundbreaking work presenting the theory of evolution by natural selection; foundation of modern evolutionary biology.
related person 1: Alfred Russel Wallace (1823–1913): Co-discoverer of natural selection who independently conceived similar ideas.
related person 2: Charles Darwin (1809–1882): Author who presented the theory of evolution by natural selection.
related person 3: Thomas Henry Huxley (1825–1895): Prominent biologist who became Darwin's most vocal defender.
related event 1: Second Industrial Revolution (1870–1914): Part of broader scientific revolution of the 19th century.
related event 2: Victorian Era (1837–1901): Published during Victoria's reign, major scientific achievement of the era.
related event 3: Voyage of the HMS Beagle (1831–1836): Darwin's voyage provided crucial observations for the theory.
notes: Sold out immediately upon publication. Generated major scientific and religious controversy but was quickly embraced by the scientific community.

name: Reign of Terror
summary: Period of mass executions (1793-1794) led by the Committee of Public Safety; approximately 17,000 officially executed
related event 1: French Revolution (1789–1799): radical phase of

name: Revolutions of 1848
summary: A wave of liberal, nationalist, and democratic uprisings across Europe, often called the “Springtime of Nations.”
related person 1: Karl Marx (1818–1883): Observed the revolutions and developed his revolutionary critique of capitalism around this period.
related person 2: Lajos Kossuth (1802–1894): Led the Hungarian revolution, one of the major uprisings of 1848.
related person 3: Louis Blanc (1811–1882): French socialist whose ideas influenced the Parisian uprising of 1848.
related event 1: Second French Republic (1848–1852): Established in France as a direct result of the 1848 uprising.
related event 2: Unification of Germany (1866–1871): Nationalist sentiments from 1848 later culminated in unification.
related event 3: Unification of Italy (Risorgimento) (1848–1871): Italian uprisings in 1848 became part of the broader unification struggle.
notes: Although most uprisings failed, they left lasting legacies: constitutional reforms, abolition of serfdom in the Habsburg Empire, and political momentum for later national unifications.

name: Russo-Turkish War
summary: War between Russia and allies against Ottoman Empire; resulted in independence of Romania, Serbia, and Montenegro and autonomy for Bulgaria.
related person 1: Abdul Hamid II (1842–1918): Ottoman Sultan during the war and defeat.
related person 2: Alexander II of Russia (1818–1881): Led Russia in support of Balkan independence movements.
related event 1: Congress of Berlin (1878): Conference that revised the war's settlement.
related event 2: Victorian Era (1837–1901): Contemporary event, part of 19th century European conflicts.
notes: Treaty of San Stefano (March 3, 1878) was revised by Congress of Berlin. Major step toward dismantling Ottoman control of the Balkans.

name: Scramble for Africa
summary: Rapid European colonization and partition of Africa.
related person 1: Otto von Bismarck (1815–1898): Hosted the Berlin Conference that formalized colonial partition.
related person 2: Queen Victoria (1819–1901): Symbol of British imperial expansion into Africa.
related person 3: Wilhelm I (1797–1888): German emperor during the early phase of German colonial acquisition.
related event 1: Crimean War (1853–1856): Earlier power rivalries evolved into overseas competition.
related event 2: Expansion of Railways (1830–1870): Rail technology enabled deeper penetration and control of territories.
related event 3: Second Industrial Revolution (1870–1914): Industrial powers sought raw materials and markets in Africa.
notes: Driven by industrial demand, nationalism, and imperial competition.

name: Second French Empire
summary: Napoleon III's imperial regime; period of industrialization and modernization of France that ended with defeat in the Franco-Prussian War.
related person 1: Napoleon III (1808–1873): Nephew of Napoleon Bonaparte who ruled France as emperor.
related event 1: Franco-Prussian War (1870–1871): War that ended the Second Empire.
related event 2: Second Italian War of Independence (1859): Napoleon III's major foreign policy venture.
related event 3: Victorian Era (1837–1901): Contemporary period, Napoleon III and Victoria were contemporaries.
notes: Established after coup d'état on December 2, 1851. Era of major Paris reconstruction and economic growth. Ended with Napoleon III's capture at Sedan in 1870.

name: Second French Republic
summary: Short-lived republican government formed after the 1848 revolution in France.
related person 1: Louis Blanc (1811–1882): Served briefly in the provisional government, advocating social reforms.
related person 2: Napoleon III (1808–1873): Elected president of the Republic before proclaiming himself emperor; born Louis-Napoléon Bonaparte.
related person 3: Victor Hugo (1802–1885): Participated in politics and later chronicled the era’s struggles.
related event 1: Franco-Prussian War (1870–1871): The war ended the Second Empire that had replaced the Republic.
related event 2: Paris Commune (1871): Later radical republicanism emerged after the fall of the Second Empire.
related event 3: Revolutions of 1848 (1848–1849): Created as a direct outcome of the 1848 revolution in France.
notes: Ended when Louis-Napoleon declared himself Emperor Napoleon III.

name: Second Industrial Revolution
summary: Wave of industrialization marked by steel, electricity, and chemicals.
related person 1: Alexander II of Russia (1818–1881): Encouraged modernization and industrial development within the Russian Empire.
related person 2: Otto von Bismarck (1815–1898): Presided over Germany’s rapid industrial expansion after unification.
related person 3: Queen Victoria (1819–1901): Reigned over Britain during the height of late-19th-century industrial growth.
related event 1: American Civil War (1861–1865): Postwar developments in the United States formed part of the new industrial age.
related event 2: Expansion of Railways (1830–1870): Relied on and extended railway infrastructure.
related event 3: Scramble for Africa (1881–1914): Industrial powers sought overseas resources and markets.
notes: Laid foundations for modern industry, global trade, and technology.

name: Second Italian War of Independence
summary: War between France and Sardinia-Piedmont against Austria; resulted in Lombardy's transfer to Sardinia, advancing Italian unification.
related person 1: Camillo Benso, Count of Cavour (1810–1861): Sardinian Prime Minister who orchestrated the alliance with France.
related person 2: Napoleon III (1808–1873): Allied with Sardinia to fight Austria in exchange for Savoy and Nice.
related person 3: Victor Emmanuel II (1820–1878): King of Sardinia-Piedmont who would become first King of unified Italy.
related event 1: Crimean War (1853–1856): Sardinia's participation won allies for unification.
related event 2: Napoleonic Wars (1803–1815): Context for French involvement in Italian affairs.
related event 3: Unification of Italy (Risorgimento) (1848–1871): This war was a key stage in the unification process.
notes: Major battles at Magenta and Solferino. France gained Savoy and Nice; Sardinia gained most of Lombardy.

name: Second Schleswig War
summary: War between Denmark and Prussia-Austria over Schleswig-Holstein; Denmark's defeat led to major territorial losses and strengthened Prussia.
related person 1: Christian IX (1818–1906): King whose signing of the November Constitution triggered the conflict.
related person 2: Otto von Bismarck (1815–1898): Prussian Minister-President who provoked the war to advance German unification.
related event 1: Austro-Prussian War (1866): Prussia and Austria fought over control of the duchies gained in this war.
related event 2: Franco-Prussian War (1870–1871): The final war in Bismarck's unification strategy.
related event 3: Unification of Germany (1866–1871): This war was the first of Bismarck's three wars leading to unification.
notes: Denmark lost 40% of its territory and about one million people. The war demonstrated Prussian military strength and Bismarck's diplomatic cunning.

name: Storming of the Bastille
summary: Parisian mob stormed the Bastille fortress on July 14, 1789, marking the start of the French Revolution
related event 1: French Revolution (1789–1799): symbolic beginning of

name: Thermidorian Reaction
summary: Coup against Robespierre on 9 Thermidor (July 27, 1794), ending the Reign of Terror
related person 1: Georges Danton (1759–1794): was partly caused by execution of
related person 2: Maximilien Robespierre (1758–1794): led to execution of
related event 1: French Revolution (1789–1799): moderate phase following the Terror
related event 2: Reign of Terror (1793–1794): ended
notes: Named after 9 Thermidor Year II in the French Republican Calendar (July 27, 1794). The Republican Calendar was adopted in 1793, replacing the Gregorian calendar with 12 months of 30 days each, named after natural phenomena. Thermidor (from Greek 'thermos' = heat) was the summer month roughly corresponding to July 19–August 17.

name: Thirteenth Amendment to the US Constitution
summary: Constitutional amendment that abolished slavery and involuntary servitude throughout the United States; first of the three Reconstruction Amendments.
related person 1: Abraham Lincoln (1809–1865): President who pushed for the amendment's passage, though he was assassinated before ratification.
related person 2: Andrew Johnson (1808–1875): President who secured ratification by requiring Southern states to ratify as part of Reconstruction.
related person 3: William H. Seward (1801–1872): Secretary of State who proclaimed the amendment on December 18, 1865.
related event 1: American Civil War (1861–1865): The war led to the amendment's passage.
related event 2: Emancipation Proclamation (Proclamation 95) (1863): The amendment completed what the proclamation began.
related event 3: Victorian Era (1837–1901): Contemporary period.
notes: Passed by Senate April 8, 1864, and House January 31, 1865. Ratified December 6, 1865 when Georgia became the 27th state to ratify. Proclaimed December 18, 1865. Exception clause allows involuntary servitude as punishment for crime.

name: Unification of Germany
summary: The process, driven largely by Prussia, that united numerous German states into the German Empire.
related person 1: Helmuth von Moltke the Elder (1800–1891): Directed Prussian military campaigns crucial to unification.
related person 2: Otto von Bismarck (1815–1898): Orchestrated political and military moves that unified the German states.
related person 3: Wilhelm I (1797–1888): Became the first German Emperor after unification.
related event 1: Austro-Prussian War (1866): Prussian victory weakened Austria and advanced unification.
related event 2: Franco-Prussian War (1870–1871): Final conflict that rallied German states and produced the empire.
related event 3: Revolutions of 1848 (1848–1849): Earlier, failed attempts at German unity influenced later strategies.
notes: The empire was proclaimed in the Hall of Mirrors at Versailles, symbolically asserting German dominance after defeating France. This unification shifted Europe’s power balance for decades.

name: Unification of Italy (Risorgimento)
summary: Series of political and military efforts to unify the Italian peninsula.
related person 1: Giuseppe Mazzini (1805–1872): Prominent Italian nationalist whose ideas inspired the Risorgimento.
related person 2: Napoleon III (1808–1873): Supported and then constrained Italian unification efforts through diplomacy and war.
related person 3: Queen Victoria (1819–1901): British monarch whose government often backed Italian national aspirations.
related event 1: Crimean War (1853–1856): Participation by Piedmont-Sardinia won allies useful for unification.
related event 2: Revolutions of 1848 (1848–1849): Italian uprisings in 1848 were key stages of the Risorgimento.
related event 3: Unification of Germany (1866–1871): Both processes reflected 19th-century nationalist movements.
notes: Completed with Rome becoming the capital.

name: Venezuelan War of Independence
summary: Venezuelan struggle for independence from Spanish colonial rule; achieved through prolonged military campaigns led by Bolívar culminating in the Battle of Carabobo and establishment of Gran Colombia.
related person 1: Antonio José de Sucre (1795–1830): Bolívar's chief lieutenant who commanded crucial victories including Ayacucho.
related person 2: Simón Bolívar (1783–1830): Commander and political leader who led the independence movement and liberated Venezuela.
related event 1: Congress of Angostura (1819): Established Gran Colombia during the independence struggle.
related event 2: Napoleonic Wars (1803–1815): Spain's involvement in European conflicts weakened colonial control, enabling independence movements.
related event 3: Victorian Era (1837–1901): Later contemporary period.
notes: First Republic declared July 5, 1811, but collapsed after 1812 earthquake. Bolívar's Admirable Campaign of 1813 established Second Republic, which also fell. Battle of Boyacá (August 7, 1819) liberated New Granada. Decisive Battle of Carabobo (June 24, 1821) secured Venezuelan independence. Final Spanish forces defeated at Lake Maracaibo naval battle (July 24, 1823).

name: Vicksburg campaign
summary: Union campaign culminating in the siege and capture of Vicksburg, giving the Union control of the Mississippi River; Grant's forces won five battles in three weeks before besieging the city for 40 days until Confederate surrender on July 4, 1863.
related person 1: Ulysses S. Grant (1822–1885): Commanded Union Army of the Tennessee in the campaign called "the most brilliant and innovative campaign of the Civil War".
related event 1: American Civil War (1861–1865): The campaign was a decisive turning point in the war.
related event 2: Appomattox Campaign (1865): Grant's later campaign that ended the war.
related event 3: Emancipation Proclamation (Proclamation 95) (1863): Occurred during the same period.
notes: Campaign began in 1862. Grant crossed Mississippi River at Bruinsburg, won battles at Port Gibson, Raymond, and Jackson (captured May 14, 1863). Siege began May 25, 1863 after failed assaults May 19 and 22. Confederate General John C. Pemberton surrendered July 4, 1863, giving Union control of the Mississippi River. Historian James McPherson called it "the most brilliant and innovative campaign of the Civil War."

name: Victorian Era
summary: Period of Queen Victoria's reign marked by British industrial dominance, vast imperial expansion, and major social and scientific changes.
related person 1: Benjamin Disraeli (1804–1881): Prime Minister who had an exceptionally close relationship with Victoria and made her Empress of India.
related person 2: Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha (1819–1861): Victoria's consort whose death in 1861 profoundly affected the queen and the era.
related person 3: Queen Victoria (1819–1901): Reigned for 63 years, longest in British history at the time.
related event 1: Industrial Revolution (c. 1760–c. 1840): The Victorian Era saw the culmination and continuation of industrialization.
related event 2: Scramble for Africa (1881–1914): British imperial expansion was a defining feature of the era.
related event 3: Second Industrial Revolution (1870–1914): Major overlap with the late Victorian period drove further technological advances.
notes: Britain became the world's first global industrial power. The empire expanded to rule one-fourth of the global population.

name: Voyage of the HMS Beagle
summary: Scientific expedition during which Darwin developed key evolutionary insights.
related person 1: Alfred Russel Wallace (1823–1913): Later independently conceived a theory of evolution by natural selection, closely linked to Darwin’s work.
related person 2: Charles Darwin (1809–1882): Sailed on HMS Beagle, gathering observations that led to his theory of evolution.
related person 3: Thomas Henry Huxley (1825–1895): Became a leading defender of Darwin’s ideas after the voyage’s scientific results were published.
related event 1: Industrial Revolution (c. 1760–c. 1840): Took place during a period of expanding scientific curiosity and exploration.
related event 2: Scramble for Africa (1881–1914): Scientific exploration and classification later intersected with imperial expansion.
related event 3: Second Industrial Revolution (1870–1914): The science it inspired fed into later technological advances.
notes: Provided Darwin with crucial observations that led to his theory of natural selection.
